H0.text: Boiling is the point the water has reached when the teacher heats a pot of water and it reaches 100°C.

H1.text: Melting is the point the water has reached once the teacher heats a pot of water to 100°C.

H2.text: Freezing is the point that the water has reached when the teacher heats a pot of water to 100 °C.

H3.text: Evaporating is the point that the water has reached when the teacher heats a pot of water to 100 °C.

A4.text: The boiling point of water is 100°C under standard atmospheric pressure at sea level.

A5.text: Evaporation occurs at temperatures below the boiling point, as it is a surface phenomenon where molecules escape without forming vapor bubbles within the liquid.
